questions.question: Write True or False and justify your answer: Two chords AB and CD of a circle are each at distances 4 cm from the centre. Then AB = CD.
questions.solution: Chords equidistant from the centre of a circle are equal in length. Since both chords are at a distance of 4 cm from the centre, their lengths must be equal.
questions.diagram: <svg width='200' height='200' viewBox='0 0 200 200'><circle cx='100' cy='100' r='80' fill='none' stroke='#333' stroke-width='2'/><line x1='40' y1='60' x2='160' y2='60' stroke='#333' stroke-width='2'/><text x='30' y='65' font-size='12'>A</text><text x='165' y='65' font-size='12'>B</text><line x1='40' y1='140' x2='160' y2='140' stroke='#333' stroke-width='2'/><text x='30' y='145' font-size='12'>C</text><text x='165' y='145' font-size='12'>D</text><circle cx='100' cy='100' r='2' fill='black'/><text x='105' y='105' font-size='12'>O</text><line x1='100' y1='100' x2='100' y2='60' stroke='#333' stroke-dasharray='4'/><line x1='100' y1='100' x2='100' y2='140' stroke='#333' stroke-dasharray='4'/><text x='105' y='80' font-size='10'>4cm</text><text x='105' y='125' font-size='10'>4cm</text></svg>

questions.question: Write True or False and justify your answer: Two chords AB and AC of a circle with centre O are on the opposite sides of OA. Then $\angle OAB = \angle OAC$.
questions.solution: The angles $\angle OAB$ and $\angle OAC$ will be equal only if the chords are equal (AB = AC). If the chord lengths are different, the triangles $\triangle OAB$ and $\triangle OAC$ are not congruent in a way that makes these specific angles equal.
questions.diagram: <svg width='200' height='200' viewBox='0 0 200 200'><circle cx='100' cy='100' r='80' fill='none' stroke='#333' stroke-width='2'/><line x1='100' y1='100' x2='100' y2='20' stroke='#333' stroke-width='2'/><text x='100' y='115' font-size='12'>O</text><text x='95' y='15' font-size='12'>A</text><line x1='100' y1='20' x2='170' y2='80' stroke='#333' stroke-width='2'/><text x='175' y='85' font-size='12'>B</text><line x1='100' y1='20' x2='40' y2='120' stroke='#333' stroke-width='2'/><text x='30' y='125' font-size='12'>C</text><line x1='100' y1='100' x2='170' y2='80' stroke='#333' stroke-dasharray='4'/><line x1='100' y1='100' x2='40' y2='120' stroke='#333' stroke-dasharray='4'/></svg>

questions.question: Write True or False and justify your answer: Two congruent circles with centres O and O' intersect at two points A and B. Then $\angle AOB = \angle AO'B$.
questions.solution: In congruent circles, equal chords subtend equal angles at the centres. Here, the chord AB is common to both circles. Therefore, it subtends equal angles at the centres O and O'.
questions.diagram: <svg width='200' height='200' viewBox='0 0 200 200'><circle cx='70' cy='100' r='60' fill='none' stroke='#333' stroke-width='2'/><circle cx='130' cy='100' r='60' fill='none' stroke='#333' stroke-width='2'/><text x='60' y='105' font-size='12'>O</text><text x='135' y='105' font-size='12'>O'</text><circle cx='100' cy='50' r='2' fill='black'/><text x='95' y='45' font-size='12'>A</text><circle cx='100' cy='150' r='2' fill='black'/><text x='95' y='165' font-size='12'>B</text><line x1='70' y1='100' x2='100' y2='50' stroke='#333' stroke-dasharray='2'/><line x1='70' y1='100' x2='100' y2='150' stroke='#333' stroke-dasharray='2'/><line x1='130' y1='100' x2='100' y2='50' stroke='#333' stroke-dasharray='2'/><line x1='130' y1='100' x2='100' y2='150' stroke='#333' stroke-dasharray='2'/></svg>

questions.question: Write True or False and justify your answer: Through three collinear points a circle can be drawn.
questions.solution: A circle can pass through three points only if they are non-collinear. If points are collinear, they lie on a straight line, and a circle (which has constant curvature) cannot pass through all three.
questions.diagram: <svg width='200' height='100' viewBox='0 0 200 100'><line x1='20' y1='50' x2='180' y2='50' stroke='#333' stroke-width='2'/><circle cx='50' cy='50' r='3' fill='black'/><text x='50' y='70' font-size='12'>A</text><circle cx='100' cy='50' r='3' fill='black'/><text x='100' y='70' font-size='12'>B</text><circle cx='150' cy='50' r='3' fill='black'/><text x='150' y='70' font-size='12'>C</text></svg>

questions.question: Write True or False and justify your answer: A circle of radius 3 cm can be drawn through two points A, B such that AB = 6 cm.
questions.solution: Since the radius is 3 cm, the diameter is $2 \times 3 = 6$ cm. Since the distance between A and B is exactly 6 cm, A and B can be the endpoints of a diameter of the circle.
questions.diagram: <svg width='200' height='200' viewBox='0 0 200 200'><circle cx='100' cy='100' r='60' fill='none' stroke='#333' stroke-width='2'/><line x1='40' y1='100' x2='160' y2='100' stroke='#333' stroke-width='2'/><text x='30' y='105' font-size='12'>A</text><text x='165' y='105' font-size='12'>B</text><circle cx='100' cy='100' r='2' fill='black'/><text x='95' y='90' font-size='12'>O</text><text x='90' y='120' font-size='10'>6 cm</text></svg>

questions.question: Write True or False and justify your answer: If AOB is a diameter of a circle and C is a point on the circle, then $AC^2 + BC^2 = AB^2$.
questions.solution: Since AOB is a diameter, the angle subtended by it at any point C on the circle is a right angle (Angle in a semicircle). Thus, $\triangle ABC$ is a right-angled triangle at C. By Pythagoras theorem, $AC^2 + BC^2 = AB^2$.
questions.diagram: <svg width='200' height='200' viewBox='0 0 200 200'><path d='M 20 100 A 80 80 0 0 1 180 100' fill='none' stroke='#333' stroke-width='2'/><line x1='20' y1='100' x2='180' y2='100' stroke='#333' stroke-width='2'/><text x='10' y='105' font-size='12'>A</text><text x='185' y='105' font-size='12'>B</text><text x='100' y='115' font-size='12'>O</text><line x1='20' y1='100' x2='100' y2='20' stroke='#333' stroke-width='2'/><line x1='180' y1='100' x2='100' y2='20' stroke='#333' stroke-width='2'/><text x='95' y='15' font-size='12'>C</text><rect x='95' y='25' width='10' height='10' fill='none' stroke='#333' transform='rotate(45 100 20)'/></svg>

questions.question: Write True or False and justify your answer: ABCD is a cyclic quadrilateral such that $\angle A = 90^\circ, \angle B = 70^\circ, \angle C = 95^\circ, \angle D = 105^\circ$.
questions.solution:
In a cyclic quadrilateral, the sum of opposite angles must be $180^\circ$.
Here, $\angle A + \angle C = 90^\circ + 95^\circ = 185^\circ \neq 180^\circ$.
Also, $\angle B + \angle D = 70^\circ + 105^\circ = 175^\circ \neq 180^\circ$.
Therefore, ABCD cannot be a cyclic quadrilateral.
questions.diagram: <svg width='200' height='200' viewBox='0 0 200 200'><polygon points='50,150 150,150 170,50 30,50' fill='none' stroke='#333' stroke-width='2'/><text x='20' y='50' font-size='12'>A</text><text x='180' y='50' font-size='12'>B</text><text x='160' y='160' font-size='12'>C</text><text x='40' y='160' font-size='12'>D</text></svg>

questions.question: Write True or False and justify your answer: If A, B, C, D are four points such that $\angle BAC = 30^\circ$ and $\angle BDC = 60^\circ$, then D is the centre of the circle through A, B and C.
questions.solution: The angle subtended by an arc at the centre is double the angle subtended by it at any point on the remaining part of the circle. Here, $\angle BDC = 60^\circ$ and $\angle BAC = 30^\circ$. Since $60^\circ = 2 \times 30^\circ$, point D satisfies the property of being the centre relative to point A on the circumference.
questions.diagram: <svg width='200' height='200' viewBox='0 0 200 200'><circle cx='100' cy='100' r='80' fill='none' stroke='#333' stroke-width='2'/><text x='100' y='115' font-size='12'>D (Centre)</text><circle cx='100' cy='100' r='2' fill='black'/><path d='M 60 160 L 100 100 L 140 160' fill='none' stroke='#333'/><path d='M 60 160 L 100 20 L 140 160' fill='none' stroke='#333'/><text x='50' y='170' font-size='12'>B</text><text x='145' y='170' font-size='12'>C</text><text x='95' y='15' font-size='12'>A</text></svg>

questions.question: Write True or False and justify your answer: If A, B, C and D are four points such that $\angle BAC = 45^\circ$ and $\angle BDC = 45^\circ$, then A, B, C, D are concyclic.
questions.solution: If two points (A and D) subtend equal angles at the line segment joining the other two points (BC) on the same side, then the four points are concyclic. Here $\angle BAC = \angle BDC = 45^\circ$, so A, B, C, D lie on the same circle.
questions.diagram: <svg width='200' height='200' viewBox='0 0 200 200'><circle cx='100' cy='100' r='80' fill='none' stroke='#333' stroke-dasharray='4'/><line x1='50' y1='150' x2='150' y2='150' stroke='#333' stroke-width='2'/><text x='40' y='160' font-size='12'>B</text><text x='160' y='160' font-size='12'>C</text><path d='M 50 150 L 80 40 L 150 150' fill='none' stroke='#333'/><text x='75' y='35' font-size='12'>A</text><path d='M 50 150 L 120 40 L 150 150' fill='none' stroke='#333'/><text x='115' y='35' font-size='12'>D</text></svg>

questions.question: Write True or False and justify your answer: In Fig. 10.10, if AOB is a diameter and $\angle ADC = 120^\circ$, then $\angle CAB = 30^\circ$.
questions.solution:
ABCD is a cyclic quadrilateral. Sum of opposite angles is $180^\circ$.
$\angle ABC + \angle ADC = 180^\circ \Rightarrow \angle ABC = 180^\circ - 120^\circ = 60^\circ$.
Since AOB is a diameter, $\angle ACB = 90^\circ$ (Angle in a semicircle).
In $\triangle ABC$: $\angle CAB = 180^\circ - (\angle ACB + \angle ABC) = 180^\circ - (90^\circ + 60^\circ) = 30^\circ$.
questions.diagram: <svg width='200' height='200' viewBox='0 0 200 200'><circle cx='100' cy='100' r='80' fill='none' stroke='#333' stroke-width='2'/><line x1='20' y1='100' x2='180' y2='100' stroke='#333' stroke-width='2'/><text x='10' y='105' font-size='12'>A</text><text x='185' y='105' font-size='12'>B</text><text x='100' y='115' font-size='12'>O</text><path d='M 20 100 L 140 30 L 180 100' fill='none' stroke='#333'/><text x='135' y='25' font-size='12'>C</text><path d='M 20 100 L 60 160 L 140 30' fill='none' stroke='#333'/><text x='55' y='175' font-size='12'>D</text></svg>
